p.strong: This has been generated based on a default for EU countries and needs to be localised for Romania. Please help us! Contact certificate@theodi.org

help.p: This self-assessment questionnaire generates an open data certificate and badge you can publish to tell people all about this open data. We also use your answers to learn how organisations publish open data.
When you answer these questions it demonstrates your efforts to comply with relevant legislation. You should also check which other laws and policies apply to your sector.
You do not need to answer all the questions to get a certificate. Just answer those you can.

group.label: Rights
group.help: your right to share this data with people

question.label: Do you have the rights to publish this data as open data?

option.label: yes, you have the rights to publish this data as open data
no, you don't have the rights to publish this data as open data
you're not sure if you have the rights to publish this data as open data

question.help: If your organisation didn't originally create or gather this data then you might not have the right to publish it. If you’re not sure, check with the data owner because you will need their permission to publish it.

if.requirement: You must have the right to publish your data.

question.label: Was all this data originally created or gathered by you?

yesno.yes: originally created or generated by its curator

question.help: If any part of this data was sourced outside your organisation by other individuals or organisations then you need to give extra information about your right to publish it.

question.label: Was some of this data extracted or calculated from other data?
question.help: An extract or smaller part of someone else's data still means your rights to use it might be affected. There might also be legal issues if you analysed their data to produce new results from it.

if.requirement: You indicated that this data wasn't originally created or gathered by you, and wasn't crowdsourced, so it must have been extracted or calculated from other data sources.

question.label: Are all sources of this data already published as open data?
question.help: You're allowed to republish someone else's data if it's already under an open data licence or if their rights have expired or been waived. If any part of your data is not like this then you'll need legal advice before you can publish it.

if.requirement: You should get legal advice to make sure you have the right to publish this data.

question.label: Was some of this data crowdsourced?
question.help: If your data includes information contributed by people outside your organisation, you need their permission to publish their contributions as open data.

if.requirement: You indicated that the data wasn't originally created or gathered by you, and wasn't extracted or calculated from other data, so it must have been crowdsourced.

question.label: Did contributors to your data use their judgement?
question.help: If people used their creativity or judgement to contribute data then they have copyright over their work. For example, writing a description or deciding whether or not to include some data in a dataset would require judgement. So contributors must transfer or waive their rights, or license the data to you before you can publish it.

question.display: The Contributor Licence Agreement is at
question.label: Where is the Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA)?
question.help: Give a link to an agreement that shows contributors allow you to reuse their data. A CLA will either transfer contributor's rights to you, waive their rights, or license the data to you so you can publish it.

question.label: Have all contributors agreed to the Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA)?
question.help: Check all contributors agree to a CLA before you reuse or republish their contributions. You should keep a record of who gave contributions and whether or not they agree to the CLA.
question.requirement: You must get contributors to agree to a Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA) that gives you the right to publish their work as open data.

question.display: The sources of this data are described at
question.label: Where do you describe sources of this data?
question.help: Give a URL that documents where your data was sourced from (its provenance) and the rights under which you publish the data. Do this even if the data wasn't originally created or gathered by you and even though you have the rights to publish it.
question.requirement: You should document where your data came from and the rights under which you publish it, so people are assured they can use parts which came from third parties.

question.label: Is documentation about the sources of this data also in machine-readable format?

yesno.yes: machine-readable data about the sources of this data

question.help: Information about data sources should be human-readable so people can understand it, as well as in a metadata format that computers can process. When everyone does this it helps other people find out how the same open data is being used and justify its ongoing publication.
question.requirement: You should include machine-readable data about the sources of your data.

group.label: Licensing
group.help: how you give people permission to use your data

question.display: Copyright and database rights are described at
question.label: Where do you describe copyright and database rights?
question.help: Give a URL to a rights statement which shows who owns copyright and database rights to the data. This statement also says what you allow people to do with this data under licence and it helps them understand the terms under which you make it available.
question.requirement: You should have a web page that states your copyright and details of how people should give attribution to your data.

question.display: The rights statement includes data about
question.label: Does your rights statement include machine-readable versions of

option.label: licences
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about licences which affect your data so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: attribution
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about attribution of your data so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: attribution URL
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about the URL of your data that must be linked to, so automatic tools can use it.

question.help: It's good practice to embed information about licences in machine-readable formats so people can automatically attribute your data back to you when they use it.

question.label: Under which licence can people reuse this data?

select.option: Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL)
Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence (PDDL)

question.help: Remember that whoever originally gathers, creates, verifies or presents a database automatically gets rights over it. So people need a waiver or a licence which proves that they can use the data and explains how they can do that legally. We list the most common licenses here; if there are no database rights, they've expired, or you've waived them, choose 'Not applicable'.

question.display: This data is not licensed because
question.label: Why does a licence not apply to this data?

option.display: there are no database rights in it
option.label: there are no database rights in this data
option.help: Database rights apply if you spent substantial effort gathering, verifying or presenting it. There are no database rights if, for example, the data is created from scratch, presented in an obvious way, and not checked against anything.

option.label: database rights have expired
option.help: Database rights last ten years. If data was last changed over ten years ago then database rights have expired.

option.label: database rights have been waived
option.help: This means no one owns the rights and anyone can do whatever they want with this data.

question.display: Database rights have been waived with
question.label: Which waiver do you use to waive database rights?

select.option: Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence (PDDL)

question.help: You need a statement to show people you've done this so that they understand they can do whatever they like with this data. Standard waivers already exist like PDDL and CCZero but you can write your own with legal advice.

question.display: Database rights have been waived with
question.label: Where is the waiver for the database rights?
question.help: Give a URL to your own publicly available waiver so people can check that it does waive your database rights.

question.label: What is the name of your licence?
question.help: If you use a different licence, we need the name so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate.

question.label: Where is your licence?
question.help: Give a URL to the licence, so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate and check that it's publicly available.

question.label: Is the licence an open licence?
question.help: If you aren't sure what an open licence is then read the Open Knowledge Definition definition. Next, choose your licence from the Open Definition Advisory Board open licence list. If a licence isn't in their list, it's either not open or hasn't been assessed yet.
question.requirement: You must publish open data under an open licence so that people can use it.

question.label: Under which licence can others reuse content?
question.help: Remember that whoever spends intellectual effort creating content automatically gets rights over it but creative content does not include facts. So people need a waiver or a licence which proves that they can use the content and explains how they can do that legally. We list the most common licenses here; if there is no copyright in the content, it's expired, or you've waived them, choose 'Not applicable'.

question.display: The content in this data is not licensed because
question.label: Why doesn't a licence apply to this data?

option.label: there is no copyright in this data
option.help: Copyright only applies to data if you spent intellectual effort creating what's in it, for example, by writing text that's within the data, or deciding whether particular data is included. There's no copyright if the data only contains facts where no judgements were made about whether to include them or not.

option.label: copyright has expired
option.help: Copyright lasts for a fixed amount of time, based on either the number of years after the death of its creator or its publication. You should check when the content was created or published because if that was a long time ago, copyright might have expired.

option.label: copyright has been waived
option.help: This means no one owns copyright and anyone can do whatever they want with this data.

question.label: Which waiver do you use to waive copyright?
question.help: You need a statement to show people you've done this, so they understand that they can do whatever they like with this data. Standard waivers already exist like CCZero but you can write your own with legal advice.

question.label: Where is the waiver for the copyright?
question.help: Give a URL to your own publicly available waiver so people can check that it does waive your copyright.

question.label: What's the name of the licence?
question.help: If you use a different licence, we need its name so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate.

question.label: Where is the licence?
question.help: Give a URL to the licence, so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate and check that it's publicly available.

question.label: Is the licence an open licence?
question.help: If you aren't sure what an open licence is then read the Open Knowledge Definition definition. Next, choose your licence from the Open Definition Advisory Board open licence list. If a licence isn't in their list, it's either not open or hasn't been assessed yet.
question.requirement: You must publish open data under an open licence so that people can use it.

question.label: Can individuals be identified from this data?

option.label: no, the data is not about people or their activities
option.help: Remember that individuals can still be identified even if data isn't directly about them. For example, road traffic flow data combined with an individual's commuting patterns could reveal information about that person.

option.label: no, the data has been aggregated so individuals can't be identified
option.help: Statistical analysis can aggregate data so that individuals are no longer be identifiable.

option.label: yes, there is a risk that individuals be identified, for example by third parties with access to extra information
option.help: Some data is legitimately about individuals like civil service pay or public expenses for example.

question.label: Has your anonymisation process been independently audited?
question.requirement: You should have your anonymisation process audited independently to ensure it reduces the risk of individuals being reidentified.

question.display: This data about individuals has been
question.label: Have you attempted to reduce or remove the possibility of individuals being identified?
question.help: Anonymisation reduces the risk of individuals being identified from the data you publish. The best technique to use depends on the kind of data you have.

question.display: By law, this data about individuals
question.label: Are you required or permitted by law to publish this data about individuals?
question.requirement: You should only publish personal data without anonymisation if you are required or permitted to do so by law.

question.display: The right to publish this data about individuals is documented at
question.label: Where do you document your right to publish data about individuals?
question.requirement: You should document your right to publish data about individuals for people who use your data and for those affected by disclosure.

question.label: Have you assessed the risks of disclosing personal data?

yesno.yes: carried out a privacy risk assessment
yesno.no: not carried out a privacy risk assessment

question.help: A risk assessment measures risks to the privacy of individuals in your data as well as the use and disclosure of that information.
question.requirement: You should assess the risks of disclosing personal data if you publish data about individuals.

question.display: The risk assessment is published at
question.label: Where is your risk assessment published?
question.help: Give a URL to where people can check how you have assessed the privacy risks to individuals. This may be redacted or summarised if it contains sensitive information.
question.requirement: You should publish your privacy risk assessment so people can understand how you have assessed the risks of disclosing data.

question.label: Has your risk assessment been independently audited?
question.help: It's good practice to check your risk assessment was done correctly. Independent audits by specialists or third-parties tend to be more rigorous and impartial.
question.requirement: You should have your risk assessment audited independently to ensure it has been carried out correctly.

question.display: Individuals affected by this data have this privacy notice
question.label: Where is the privacy notice for individuals affected by your data?
question.help: When you collect data about individuals you must tell them how that data will be used. People who use your data need this to make sure they comply with data protection legislation.
question.requirement: You should tell people what purposes the individuals in your data consented to you using their data for so that they use your data for the same purposes and comply with data protection legislation.

question.label: Is there someone in your organisation who is responsible for data protection?

question.display: The individual responsible for data protection
question.label: Have you involved them in the risk assessment process?
question.requirement: You should involve the person responsible for data protection in your organisation before you publish this data.

question.display: The anonymisation of the data has been
question.label: Has your anonymisation approach been independently audited?
question.help: It is good practice to make sure your process to remove personal identifiable data works properly. Independent audits by specialists or third-parties tend to be more rigorous and impartial.
question.requirement: You should have your anonymisation process audited independently by an expert to ensure it is appropriate for your data.
